timeline.bodyText: ctx.writeAndFlush would do the work. By the way, maybe we can do ctx.isOpen check before we write, it, the connection might be closed before server got a chance to write.
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText: add a channel.isOpen() check in AmbrySendToHttp2Adaptor.
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText: ctx.writeAndFlush() doesn't work. It writes data to the outboundhandlers before it. ctx.channel().writeAndFlush() is used, which will write data from the tail of the pipeline.
replies.author: zzmao

timeline.bodyText: what happened to connetionstats handler, why we drop it here.
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

timeline.bodyText: I would go against using writeAndFlush here, this is a write method, it should just call ctx.write and let the caller do writeAndFlush.
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText:
I am a little worry about using write() only.
Did some reading, but still not sure if the caller's writeAndFlush can trigger writeAndFlush through all the pipeline.
Any drawback to use writeAndFlush() here?
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText:
A caller calling writeAndFlush here will likely result in a call to AbstractChannelHandlerContext.writeAndFlush which calls invokeWriteAndFlush. This appears to call flush, but feeds the promise only to the write call (invokeWrite0). I'm pretty sure the promise is only completed once the message is actually flushed though.
So, I feel that the difference between just calling write here vs calling writeAndFlush would be that flush would be called twice in a row if the caller already calls writeAndFlush.
replies.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText: as per my understanding the functional difference between write and writeAndFlush is that writeAndFlush writes the data immediately to the socket buffer whereas with write() the flushing to socket buffer does not happen untill a certain number of buffer is accumulated at netty layer which is controlled through setWriteBufferHighWaterMark in ChannelConfig i think. Usually writeAndFlush() is needed for latency sensitive protocols, it may a bit costly if lots of small messages are being sent out using writeAndFlush.
replies.author: ssen-li
zzmao

timeline.author: cgtz

timeline.bodyText: This metric seems to just record the time it takes to call requestQueue.put, which should be short unless the queue is full. Is that intended? Is there another metric to record the time the request spends in the queue?
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText:
yes, i have an impression that we hit  queue blocking issue before. Use this metric to reminder use.
Queuing metric is also import, added a new one.
Good catch!

timeline.bodyText: Where is the CONTENT_LENGTH header set now since it's being removed from here?
timeline.author: ssen-li

replies.bodyText: It was used because we reused frontend NettyMessageProcessor which has a dependency on CONTENT_LENGTH. Since we totally dropped NettyMessageProcessor, CONTENT_LENGTH is no longer needed.
replies.author: zzmao
